III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv)Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth’s
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff called Complainant and heard staff yelling at youths over the
phone.
Investigation This incident occurred on 1/7/24 and I was assigned to investigate
it on 1/16/24. The Placement Collaboration Unit was also
assigned.
Interviews:
I contacted Complainant/Youth J’s mother on 1/16/24. She stated
Med Tech called her on 1/7/24 and through the phone, she heard
Med Tech and other female staff yelling at youths. “I was
petrified. I didn’t feel safe.” I asked Complainant if she knew why
Med Tech called her. She said she thought Youth J had told Med
Tech that the Complainant would come “whip the Med Tech’s
behind.” Complainant was unwilling or unable to provide specific
details relative to her phone conversation with Med Tech.
I notified Youth J’s Foster Care Worker via email of the assigned
investigation. His worker expressed no additional licensing
concerns.
I interviewed Youth J on 1/17/24. He has been at two different
detention facilities and said he likes Mott Children’s Residence
best because he has more freedom. I asked Youth J about staff
yelling at him or other youths while Med Tech was on the phone
with his mother. He said he did not know why Med Tech called
his mother, but “she called in front of all the kids and stopped
passing meds for that.” Youth J could not remember what staff
was supervising him or what other youths heard the Med Tech’s
side of the phone conversation.
2

I asked Youth J about the plan MDHHS has for him. He said the
plan is to reunite with his mother, but he does not want to reunite
with her and prefers to be placed in a foster home. “I don’t want to
live with her,” he insisted.
I interviewed Med Tech, also Certified Nurse Assistant (CNA) on
1/17/24. She has worked at the facility almost two years and said
she is trained in physical management. Med Tech said she works
in the medical office and is not a direct care staff working on the
residential units.
When Youth J arrived at the medication window, Med Tech said
she offered him Tylenol as needed for pain. Youth J told her
Complainant told him he could have Ibuprofen. Med Tech clarified
that Youth J’s doctor wants him to take Tylenol. “Youth J wouldn’t
remove himself from the med window so I could finish passing
medication. I called his mother to tell her it was wrong to tell her
son that he could have Ibuprofen when she knew his doctor
ordered Tylenol. Complainant asked, ‘Why are you calling me
with this shit?’ I explained I am the nurse and Youth J is giving
me a hard time at the med window.” Instead of listening to her,
Med Tech said Complainant focused on the noise in the
background. “I told her ‘Your son is refusing and bullying staff with
you overpowering what we are capable of doing and not doing,
and he’s threatening us for that. Complainant argued and still
wanted me to give Youth J Ibuprofen. The kids were getting loud
and impatient. Staff 2 (who works at a sister facility) came and
told me I shouldn’t be on the phone, which I thought was rude. I
just wanted us (Mott staff and Complainant) to be on the same
side. I hoped calling her would get him to move, but it didn’t.”
I asked Med Tech if she thought to contact the supervisor on duty
when Youth J refused to move from the medication window. She
said she did not. I asked if she or other staff in the hall were
yelling at any youth. Med Tech said staff were trying to de-
escalate youth but not yelling at them. I asked again if she or any
staff were yelling. Med Tech said Staff 2 yelled, but she yelled at
Med Tech, not at the youths.
I attempted to interview Staff 2 in person on 1/17/24, but she was
not working that day. On 1/19/24, I interviewed her via phone.
Staff 2 said she works at Whaley’s sister facility and does not work
at Mott Children’s Residence. She said she and two staff from the
other facility brought five youths to the medication room in Mott for
Med Tech to dispense their medication. “I observed Youth J at
the window with Med Tech on the phone…I don’t know what Mott
3

staff were there. Youth J was loud and rude to Med Tech. He
said he told Med Tech to call his mother so the youths knew she
was talking to his mother. I calmed Youth J down after a couple
minutes and took him to his unit…Med Tech was on the phone
pretty long, so I redirected her to end the conversation.”
Staff 2 denied that she, Med Tech, or anyone else were yelling at
the youths. She also denied yelling at Med Tech.
I asked HR Director how Complainant typically interacts with staff
at the facility. She stated, “Complainant is irrational at times and
does not always follow court orders or residential protocol for
visitation. Youth J has refused to see Complainant due to feeling
embarrassed by her behaviors. Complainant has cussed out
various staff on the phone and in person. When she’s riled, she
returns to issues from the past even though they were already
addressed. Complainant has threatened to sue the agency,
record conversations and cause staff to lose their jobs.”
HR Director read aloud a portion of the updated service plan by
Staff 7 dated November 2023. “Complainant has not participated
in a court-ordered psychological evaluation, family therapy or
parenting classes. She struggles with emotional stability, talks
over others, and argues that proper efforts for reunification are not
being offered.”
CONSULTATION
It is best practice that sensitive conversations with a youth’s
parent be reserved for case management and administrative staff.
Analysis Med Tech contacted Complainant about Youth J’s behavior, and
by doing so, may have acted outside of her designated role.
However, there is no evidence that any staff were yelling at the
youth.
Conclusion Violation not established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4146 Immunizations.
Section
Description (4) Nothing in the rules adopted under 1973 PA 116 shall
authorize or require immunizations for any child whose parent
objects on religious grounds. If a parent objects to immunizations
on religious grounds, the objection shall be made in writing to the
institution and retained in the resident’s file.
4

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Vaccine given to Youth J without parent's permission. Parent
objects based on religious grounds.
Investigation Interview:
Complainant reported Youth J was vaccinated at the facility
without her consent.
Documentation reviewed:
Youth J’s immunization record as of 8/3/23 indicated he has not
received any vaccinations since 10/06/21. Youth J was placed at
the facility on 12/13/22.
An email exchange between Complainant and Staff 7 dated
8/29/23 indicated Complainant instructed Staff 7 to never give
Youth J immunizations, including COVID, without her consent due
to the family’s religious beliefs. Staff 7 responded confirming
Youth J has not received any vaccines since he was placed at the
facility.
Analysis Youth J’s immunization record indicates his parent’s wishes were
honored and he has not received vaccinations since he was
admitted to the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
Section
Description The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation At age 14, Youth J was sexually abused by a 16-year-old. It
appears Youth J's sexual safety plan has not been implemented.
Investigation Documents reviewed:
I reviewed an internal email exchange from Staff 6 to the facility’s
Education Coordinator, HR Director, Director of Clinical Services
and Director of Residential Services dated 3/1/23. The email
contained an email exchange between Staff 6 and Youth J’s
5

school. A female student at Flex High in Burton reported to a
teacher that she and Youth J had sex in the bathroom at the
public school they both attended.
I reviewed Youth J’s written sexual safety plan effective 2/28/23.
The plan was detailed and extensive.
Interviews:
Complainant stated Youth J was sexually abused by a 16-year-
old.
HR Director stated the alleged sexual incident happened last year
at Flex High School, not at the facility. The female student
involved was not a Mott resident, but a former resident from Mott’s
sister facility. She said the alleged sexual encounter was reported
to Centralized Intake and was transferred to law enforcement.
The facility had Youth J tested for sexually transmitted diseases.
A sexual safety plan for Youth J was developed and implemented
on 2/28/23. The plan was distributed to residential managers and
placed in a binder on Youth J’s living unit.
Analysis The alleged sexual assault on Youth J occurred at school and not
at the licensed child caring institution. Nonetheless, a sexual
safety plan was developed for Youth J and implemented at the
facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4123 Education
Section
Description (1) An institution shall not admit a child for care unless an
appropriate educational program can be provided.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Complainant/Mother is not invited timely to IEPC meetings at
Youth J's school.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant stated she is not invited to IEPC meetings in a timely
manner. “They send it the day of, and the school does not identify
me as the parent.”
I interviewed Youth J. He confirmed his mother participates in his
IEPC meetings via Zoom.
6

I interviewed HR Director at the facility on 1/17/24. She reported
Youth J has resided at Mott Children’s Residence since 12/13/22.
He received special education at two different public schools since
his admission and is currently suspended from Johnson High in
Mt. Morris.
Documents reviewed:
I reviewed a printed school email dated 10/10/23 forwarded to
Complainant from the facility inviting Complainant to Youth J’s
IEPC meeting on 10/18/23 via Zoom. HR Director indicated
Complainant attended that IEPC meeting.
I also reviewed printed email threads between the facility, school
and Complainant dated 8/24/23 showing the facility communicated
with Complainant regarding their efforts to enroll Youth J into a
new school.
An email thread between Youth J’s school and the facility dated
12/18/23 indicated Complainant contact the school and the school
was not providing her with information regarding Youth J because
she was not listed in their system as a contact person with
rights/permissions. The facility related back to the school
Complainant does have legal rights/permissions and participated
in Youth J’s IEPC meeting on 10/18/23. However, the facility did
not add Complainant to the school’s contact list because
Complainant requires supervision by facility staff in order to have
in-person or phone contact with her son.
Further an email dated 12/18/23 showed Complainant and other
interested parties were invited to attend a Manifestation
Determination Review Meeting on 1/4/24 via Zoom to determine if
Youth J’s recent suspension was the result of his disability.
Analysis The facility has made sufficient efforts to communicate education
issues and meeting with Complainant. Appropriate educational
programming is provided to Youth J through the public school
system.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
7

(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth J's behavior is getting worse. Facility is not providing
appropriate safety planning or therapy services to address Youth
J's needs.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant said Youth J’s behavior is getting worse and the
facility is not providing appropriate safety planning or anger
management therapy.
HR Director stated Youth J has exhibited no inappropriate sexual
behaviors since an incident that occurred at his public school on
2/28/23.
Documentation reviewed:
I reviewed a sexual safety plan by Director of Residential Services
for Youth J dated 2/28/23. The written safety plan was placed in a
binder on the unit and was detailed and extensive.
I reviewed a list of individual therapy sessions completed, offered,
or rescheduled with Youth J by internal and outside resources.
From 1/11/23 – 6/21/23, therapy was provided to Youth J by an
outside resource. During that period, Youth J participated in 14
sessions, refused 8, and 3 were rescheduled due to inclement
weather or therapist out of the office.
From 6/29/23 – 1/12/24, therapy was provided to Youth J directly
by the facility. During that period, Youth J participated in 25
sessions, refused 3, and 6 were rescheduled due to conflicts with
Youth J’s basketball games/practice.
Analysis Documentation showed Youth J had an appropriate safety plan in
place at the facility and individual therapy services to address his
needs were and are still being provided.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
8

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings, it is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
